topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0: DNSaaS Installation and Configuration

p.b: This document describes the installation process for HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0

body.p: Our managed DNS service, based on the OpenStack Designate project, is engineered to help you create, publish, and manage your DNS zones and records securely and efficiently to either a public or private DNS server network.
It is important to read through this page before starting your installation as it explains how to install and configure DNS as a service (DNSaaS) for HPE Helion OpenStack

li.xref: Preparing to boot the Deployer VM
Booting the Deployer VM and Uploading the Deployer Tarball
Login and Initialize the Deployer VM

ul.li: Credentials of the user+tenant where the service is to be deployed ("Target Credentials")
The SVC network correctly configured within HOS
A SSH public and private keypair
"openrc" credentials file for the Target user and project

section.title: Creating the Prerequisite Credentials
section.p: Target credentials are the credentials of the user+tenant where the service is to be deployed. Target credentials include a tenant and a username. Service credentials can only be created after the Target credentials have been successfully created.

section.title: DNSaaS User and Project Credentials
section.p: Prepare the credentials files for the DNSaaS user and project.
section.codeblock: $ cat <<EOF > dnsaas.osrc unset OS_DOMAIN_NAME export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 export OS_AUTH_VERSION=3 export OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE=internalURL export OS_INTERFACE=internal export OS_CACERT=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt export OS_PROJECT_NAME=dnsaas export OS_USERNAME=dnsaas export OS_PASSWORD=password export OS_AUTH_URL=http://192.168.245.5:35357/v3 EOF

sectiondiv.p: HPE Helion OpenStack DNSaaS has several example models that can be deployed. In the following example, the powerdns example deployment model is used.
sectiondiv.note: The cp command must be used exactly as shown - including the /* on the end of the example model path.
sectiondiv.codeblock: $ cd ~/helion $ cp -r examples/powerdns/* my_cloud/definition/ $ git add -A $ git commit -a -m "Add DNSaaS Example Model" [site aa285cf] Add DNSaaS Example Model 12 files changed, 246 insertions(+), 3 deletions(-) create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/dnsaas.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/hos.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/baremetalConfig.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/control_plane.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/disks_controller.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/interfaces_controller.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/net_global.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/network_groups.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/server_roles.yml create mode 100644 my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml

sectiondiv.p: You will need to populate the ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/hos.yml file with the appropriate URLs for your deployment. You can find the URLs in the service catalog openstack catalog list and the Keystone admin token in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf on one of the HPE Helion OpenStack control plane nodes. Other values may be left invalid, they will not prevent the deployment from completing.
sectiondiv.codeblock:
$ cd my_cloud/definition/ $ ls cloudConfig.yml config data $ nano cloudConfig.yml
[ Please fill in appropriate DNS and NTP servers and save ]
$ cd data/pass-through/ $ ls dnsaas.yml hos.yml $ nano hos.yml
[ Please fill in appropriate values and save ] [ NOTE: On this HOS deployer, execute:
cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts platform-paas-through.yml -e pass_through_key=""
and copy the contents of /home/stack/platform-paas-through.yml into hos.yml ]
$ cd ~/helion $ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model" [site 19b2f88] Configured Deployment Model 2 files changed, 13 insertions(+), 7 deletions(-)
